contents.text: Eli and the Red Hat Blown by the Wind
Eli and Mom Elephants go for a walk down at the grassland.  It is a windy day.

Wooooosh!

A strong wind blows Miss Antelope's red hat right off her head!

"Help me catch my hat. My red hat," she cries.

"Eli, let's help Miss Antelope catch her red hat," says Mama Elephant.

But Eli is scared. "If I run too fast, I will trip and fall over," says Eli.

"You'll be fine! Come on. We will start slow and get faster one step at a time," says Mama.
So the two elephants run up and down the grassland after the flying red hat blown by the wind. A strong wind.

The two elephants are sweating and a little out of breath once or twice.

"Hee hee hee! This is fun, Mom," says Eli.
Can you think of a time when you were active with your Mom/Dad/Caregiver?
contents.subtext: Active means any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath like running, playing in the park, dancing, swimming.

contents.text: What did you enjoy when you were active with your Mom/Dad/Caregiver?
Thinking about the fun things during physical activity can make it more enjoyable!
Chapter 2

The hat flies and flies, then lands on a tree. 

But it is not just any tree...

It's a baobab tree. A big, tall baobab tree.

"That’s a very tall tree," says Eli.

"How do we get Miss Antelope’s red hat?"

"I have an idea," says Mom.

"Point your trunk towards the hat," says Mama.

Eli and Mama point their big trunks at the red hat on the tall Baobab tree.

"Now one, two, three, blow that hat," yells Mom.

They blow the hat at the same time.

"Hey Mom, this is fun! I can blow the red hat on the Baobab tree!" says Eli.

"That’s because you exercise often. It makes you strong and healthy. And you will feel good about yourself” says Mama.

"Come on, let’s blow that red hat one more time."
As the elephants blow the hat once again, the hat flies off the Baobab tree and up into the air.
The wind catches the hat yet again, it flies further and further away!
Chapter 3
The wind grabs the hat, carrying the hat away from the Elephants. And suddenly...

...the hat lands on the river! The river carries the hat downstream, away from the elephants. Eventually, the hat gets caught on a branch on the opposite side of the river.

"Now how do we get the hat? It's on the other side of the river!" Eli asks.

"Just then, a green scaly creature surfaces from the river.

"Look! It’s my friend Croco!” says Eli.

"Hi Eli!" says Croco, the little green crocodile.

"Croco, can you help me catch that hat on the other side of the river?" asks Eli.

"Sure I can help you, but it would be more fun if you do it yourself," says Croco. "I can teach you how to jump across the river."

Eli is not sure. "I’m not a good jumper," says Eli.

"It's not difficult at all. I will show you how," says Croco.

Croco raises his body, leaps to one big rock on the river. Then he jumps and leaps again to land on another rock. Finally, he lands on the other side of the river.

Eli leaps to the first big rock in the river.

Then Eli jumps and leaps again to land on another rock until finally, Eli landed on the other side of the river.

"This is not difficult at all!" says Eli.

"¡Mamá! Tengo el sombrero rojo de la señorita Antelope que fue soplado por el viento", dijo Eli a su mamá.

 Pero su mamá todavía estaba al otro lado del río. 

 "Mamá tiene que llegar!" dijo Eli.
"Tienes que llegar aquí porque tienes que ver esto!", dijo Eli.
Capítulo 4

Mamá elefante quiere llegar al otro lado del río. 

 Así que ella dejó atrás a 10 pies y rápidamente caminó hasta el borde del río.

"Yipeee!", dijo mamá. 

 Después de correr y correr mientras perseguía al sombrero rojo, ella mejoró en otras actividades también! 

 "Eres bueno en esta mamá", dijo Eli.

Mamá estaba sudando y sin aliento. "Se siente bien!", dijo. 

 Entonces Eli le dijo a su mamá, "Mira eso, mamá". Apuntó con sus dedos de elefante mientras señalaba a la orilla del acantilado. 

 El sol estuvo a punto de ponerse y el valle de encima del acantilado parecía brillar.
Eli y la mamá se sentaron y miraron el sol disminuyendo — el brillo del valle verde con el sombrero rojo que fue soplado por el viento.
